Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:2.0b11pre) Gecko/20110201 Firefox/4.0b11pre

"Restore Previous Session" doesn't restore tabs if more than one window was open.  See video.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start with just the about:home page (no other tabs open = you just clicked the Firefox / Minefield icon on the Desktop).
2. Open www.microsoft.com in the first tab.
3. Open a new window using CTRL + N.
4. Navigate to www.ibm.com in the second window.
5. Close all windows.
6. Restore the Previous Session (using either the button on about:home OR the menu command).
7. Only www.microsoft.com will be restored.  IBM is NOT shown, even though it was in the Previous Session.
Actual Results:  
Restore Previous Session only has a one-window memory.

Expected Results:  
Restore Previous Session should remember multiple windows a user has open.

comments.raw_text:
I think this is as designed:

If you close a window and remain in the session, the window is restorable through Recently Closed Windows.
If you quit Firefox, it will only restore to the exact state as when it quit.

For example, I have 2 windows, close one of those windows then quit Firefox. When I start Firefox I click History > Restore Previous Session, the last window is restored.  I can then restore the second window through Recently Closed Windows.

This is by design.  Paul, please advise.  Thanks.

I started to comment before but never finished. I know this has come up before and there's probably an old bug to dupe this to but I couldn't find anything with a quick look

This is by design, but it's also unfortunate. Since there's no real distinction of "i'm closing a window and then another window that i want open" vs "i'm closing this window and this window because i'm done with both of them" vs "i want both of these when i start up but i only know how to quit by closing windows so [X], [X]"

So for now we just restore your last window and other windows are in "recently closed windows".

There are some things we could do but it's hard to define what the right thing is for everybody :/

I understand what you are saying and can see it might not be difficult to code these circumstances, but would be very intrusive to the user.  The only way I can think of to save the windows users want to save when clicking the [X] for each window is to have Firefox prompt "Do you want to save these tabs?"  Can you imagine if there were say five windows open???

[X} "Do you want to save these tabs?"  [Yes / No]
[X} "Do you want to save these tabs?"  [Yes / No]
[X} "Do you want to save these tabs?"  [Yes / No]
[X} "Do you want to save these tabs?"  [Yes / No]
[X} "Do you want to save these tabs?"  [Yes / No]

Then, if the user selects the wrong option, they will think Data Loss because Firefox didn't restore all the tabs they said to save.


In the other option, selecting "Firefox Menu" -----> Exit automatically saves everything, then the user can specify what they want during next session (ALL Windows / Tabs = "Restore Previous Session") or ("Recently Closed Tabs / Windows").


In order to save the windows users want to save without being too intrusive with the prompts would be to implement what I call Panorama Version 2.0, which can include a check box that says "Save these tabs upon close" within each group.

I have coded in Visual Basic before, so forgive me if I give you (Mozilla) some User Interface / coding suggestions.....but, hey.....isn't that what Bugzilla is for, both Bugs and new feature suggestions???

On the contrary, I am annoyed by the behaviour of Firefox in restoring windows that were closed just prior to shutting down. To see this, open a new window and navigate away from the new tab page. Close both of them in succession by clicking the red [X]. When you restart Firefox, both of them are restored.

I dislike this behaviour because I only want the tabs in my main Firefox window to reload. I believe there's some timeout before the closed window gets registered as closed, but how do I change it?
